title.justification: This title is explicitly stated at the beginning of the paper.

extractions.description: This paper introduces the Equivariant Mesh Neural Network (EMNN), a model designed for geometric deep learning on 3D triangular meshes that incorporates mesh face information and long-range interactions. The EMNN outperforms other complex equivariant methods on several mesh tasks while being computationally efficient and simple to implement.

type.justification: The paper provides experimental results comparing the proposed EMNN with other existing methods, demonstrating its efficiency and effectiveness on various datasets.
type.quote: In this section, we evaluate our models using two types of settings: one for evaluating equivariant models and another for non-equivariant models.

name.justification: Triangular meshes are often used in computer graphics and vision tasks, and the paper focuses on geometric deep learning on these 3D meshes.
name.quote: Recent advancements in 3D geometric deep learning have showcased remarkable performance across a diverse array of computer graphics and vision tasks.

name.justification: The paper focuses on algorithms and architectures that operate on geometric structures like meshes, making it a subfield of geometric deep learning.
name.quote: One way to incorporate geometry deep networks for mesh data is to make them equivariant to relevant geometric transformations, such as translations and rotations.

name.justification: The paper deals significantly with 3D object representation using triangular meshes.
name.quote: Polygon meshes, which are collections of vertices and polygons, are an alternative to point clouds and voxel-based representations of 3D objects.

name.justification: The paper's primary contribution is the Equivariant Mesh Neural Network (EMNN).
name.quote: Equivariant Mesh Neural Network(EMNN), is a simple message-passing method that proves both efficient and effective compared to all prior work.

is_contributed.justification: EMNN is introduced and developed within this paper.
is_contributed.quote: we minimally extend the update equations of E(n)-Equivariant Graph Neural Networks (EGNNs) to incorporate mesh face information, and further improve it to account for long-range interactions through hierarchy. The resulting architecture, Equivariant Mesh Neural Network(EMNN),

is_executed.justification: The paper includes experimental results obtained by executing the model, and specific details such as runtime and memory usage are mentioned.
is_executed.quote: All experiments in this section are conducted using 1 GPU Nvidia Quadro RTX 5000.

is_compared.justification: EMNN is compared against several other models like GEM-CNN, EMAN, and EGNN in terms of performance and efficiency.
is_compared.quote: Our method is compared against alternatives in table 5. EMNN achieved SOTA on 16-4 split settings, while placed second in the 10-10 settings.

referenced_paper_title.justification: EMNN is based on extending the E(n)-Equivariant Graph Neural Networks (EGNNs) method.
referenced_paper_title.quote: we minimally extend the update equations of E(n)-Equivariant Graph Neural Networks (EGNNs) (Satorras et al., 2021)

name.justification: FAUST is explicitly mentioned and used for model evaluation in the paper.
name.quote: FAUST includes 100 instances of 3-dimensional human meshes with 6890 vertices each.

referenced_paper_title.value: FAUST: Dataset and evaluation for 3D mesh registration
referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset description mentions its introduction by Bogo et al., 2014.

name.justification: TOSCA is explicitly mentioned and used for model evaluation in the paper.
name.quote: TOSCA is a 9-class mesh dataset of cats, men, women, centaurs, etc with varying nodes and edges in each mesh.

referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset description mentions its introduction by Bronstein et al., 2008.

name.justification: SHREC is explicitly mentioned and used for model evaluation in the paper.
name.quote: Datasets used to evaluate equivariant models comprise TOSCA (Bronstein et al., 2008) and FAUST (Bogo et al., 2014): ...SHREC dataset

referenced_paper_title.justification: The dataset description mentions its introduction by Lian et al., 2011.

name.justification: The source code implementation is mentioned to be in PyTorch.
name.quote: Our source code in PyTorch (Paszke et al., 2019) is at https://github.com/HySonLab/EquiMesh

referenced_paper_title.value: PyTorch: An Imperative Style, High-Performance Deep Learning Library.
referenced_paper_title.justification: The library description mentions its introduction by Paszke et al., 2019.
